author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Advances Expansive Industrial Policy Bill to Counter China
description: The vote indicated bipartisan support for the legislation, which had been at risk of being scaled back substantially until Republicans rallied around a more extensive bill.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Tuesday moved toward passing an expansive industrial policy bill to counter China’s technological and manufacturing dominance, voting to advance legislation that includes more than $52 billion in subsidies for companies that build semiconductors in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: New York Renters Are Now Paying the Price for the ‘Covid Discount’
description: More than 40 percent of the available units in Manhattan currently come from tenants priced out of apartments they leased in 2020 and 2021, according to a new StreetEasy report.
content: For comfort at the beginning of the pandemic, Cathy Linh Che turned to cooking her mother’s Vietnamese recipes. She could easily find all the ingredients she needed in Manhattan’s Chinatown. But the subway ride from her Jackson Heights, Queens, apartment was almost an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mac Schwerin
title: Why I Care More About Nonplayer Characters Than About Some Ex-Lovers
description: The members of gaming’s subordinate caste flicker with the humanity of their developers.
content: I met Karen years ago under trying circumstances. My grandfather had died and left me his farm, a dirt patch outside a tiny village. I didn’t know anyone there, or how to farm. Karen worked as a waitress at the local inn and spent her leisure time plotting an escape to some unspecified big city. She was mostly brusque, often drunk and registered annoyance at my every approach. We married within a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M. Profit Falls 40 Percent as Costs Rise and Chips Are Lacking
description: The automaker reaffirmed its forecast for earnings for the full year.
content: General Motors is now being squeezed by inflation as well as a global computer chip shortage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Stopping wildfires before they start
description: The Amazon is burning at its fastest pace in over a decade. Meet one scientist who’s trying to reverse the trend.
content: Wildfire season is back in the world’s largest rainforest, the Amazon. Last month, the Brazilian part of the forest saw the highest number of fires in 15 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: English Is Messy. Do I Have to Spell It Out?
description: Whither our aspirational Esperanto.
content: One of the best things going on around 200 B.C.E. (from this linguist’s point of view, at least) was that a librarian in Alexandria, Aristophanes of Byzantium, invented the first punctuation system that deserved the name — one better than the one we’re used to. A mark up high (“˙”) meant a full stop, like our period; in the middle (“·”) meant a brief pause, a firm but gentle separation, like our comma; and one on the bottom (“.”) meant something in between, a breather of sorts, like our semicolon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Recession: What Does It Mean?
description: Why we won’t — and shouldn’t — declare one now.
content: There’s a pretty good chance the Bureau of Economic Analysis, which produces the numbers on gross domestic product and other macroeconomic data, will declare on Thursday, preliminarily, that real G.D.P. shrank in the second quarter of 2022. Since it has already announced that real G.D.P. shrank in the first quarter, there will be a lot of breathless commentary to the effect that we’re officially in a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Love or Hate Emmanuel Carrère’s Forceful Tangents, They’re Back in ‘Yoga’
description: In Carrère’s latest, a best seller (and cause of scandal) in France, the author’s life gets very bad and then slightly better.
content: Emmanuel Carrère’s “Yoga” was released as a novel in France. Its American publisher’s website lists it under “Bios & Memoirs.” The Library of Congress calls it autobiography. On Amazon, “Yoga” is classed as both “Medical Fiction,” where it is currently the No. 248 best seller, and “Author Biographies,” where it sits at No. 340. If you’re new to Carrère and troubled by this taxonomical mayhem, the best advice is to dive in without worrying about where a bewildered librarian is going to file the book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: He’s Baseball’s Only Mud Supplier. It’s a Job He May Soon Lose.
description: Jim Bintliff collects the Delaware River mud that is smeared on Major League baseballs to make them less slippery. But that tradition is in jeopardy.
content: LONGPORT, N.J. — A 45-gallon rubber barrel sits in a cluttered garage along the Jersey Shore, filled waist-high with what looks like the world’s least appetizing chocolate pudding. It is nothing more than icky, gooey, viscous, gelatinous mud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Hotter, Longer and More Widespread Heat Waves Scorch China
description: More than 70 weather stations across the country have recorded their highest temperatures ever in recent weeks.
content: BEIJING — In western China, runoff from melting glaciers could overwhelm dams, officials have warned. In the southern metropolis of Guangzhou, the government has asked residents to use large appliances less so the electrical grid is not overwhelmed as the city battles its longest heat wave since 1951. In the coastal city of Fuzhou, temperatures exceeded 41 degrees Celsius, or nearly 106 degrees Fahrenheit, for an unprecedented three days in a row, state media reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Joni Mitchell Reclaims Her Voice at Newport
description: The singer-songwriter’s surprise return to the stage at the folk festival she first played in 1967 was an act of bravery, joy and reinterpretation.
content: This summer, quite unexpectedly, two of music’s brightest stars haven’t been fresh young upstarts, but a pair of semi-reclusive female elders whose brilliance is being reaffirmed by a new generation of fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Will Streaming Save Sports or Kill It?
description: Sports are the lifeblood of TV but also choking it. Big Tech is following a similar playbook.
content: Sports and TV have thrived together. Our entertainment future will be shaped by whether streaming and sports can repeat that mostly happy partnership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: ‘Operating With Increased Intensity’: Zuckerberg Leads Meta Into Next Phase
description: Facebook’s founder is setting a relentless pace as he pushes his company through a tech transformation during a global economic slowdown.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg, the founder and chief executive of the company formerly known as Facebook, called his top lieutenants for the social network to a last-minute meeting in the San Francisco Bay Area this month. On the agenda: a “work-athon” to discuss the road map for improving the main Facebook app, including a revamp that would change how users browse the service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Biden’s Drug Czar Is Leading the Charge for a ‘Harm Reduction’ Approach
description: Experts describe the president’s drug control strategy as the most progressive since Richard Nixon appointed the nation’s first drug czar in 1971.
content: MANCHESTER, N.H. — During a recent interview here, Dr. Rahul Gupta, President Biden’s drug czar, appeared to be on the verge of supporting a radical shift in U.S. drug control policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: DNA Researchers Name the Somerton Man, Australia’s 73-Year-Old Cold Case
description: Sleuths amateur and professional alike have been puzzled for years by the discovery in 1948 of an unidentified man’s body slumped by a sea wall near Adelaide. The South Australian police have not verified the new finding.
content: Two researchers using forensic genealogy put a name to the so-called Somerton Man this week, saying they had finally solved the central mystery of an Australian cold case that has stymied investigators for 73 years and inspired theories about spies, smuggling, ballet and teeth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Alphabet’s profit dropped 14 percent in the second quarter.
description: The earnings by Google’s parent company were below analysts’ expectations of $17.5 billion in net profit on $69.9 billion in revenue.
content: Google’s search engine business is demonstrating resilience in the face of a slowing economy and rising inflation, but its other businesses have not been able to escape a downturn in online advertising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Disabled Voters Sue Wisconsin Over Absentee Ballot Rule Change
description: The state’s Supreme Court ruled this month that only voters themselves could return their absentee ballots in person.
content: Several disabled voters are suing Wisconsin’s Elections Commission in federal court after learning that they can no longer get help returning absentee ballots, a reversal that they argue is unconstitutional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest Winner Week 5: On ‘One Small Step for Democracy in a “Live Free or Die” Town’
description: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Daniel Wei, as well as our many runners-up and honorable mentions.
content: We received 1,147 entries from students from around the world for the fifth week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Daniel Wei, as well as the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Prison Personnel Describe Horrific Conditions, and Cover-Up, at Atlanta Prison
description: The conditions at the prison, while extreme, reflect wider problems in the Bureau of Prisons’ sprawling network of 122 facilities housing about 158,000 inmates.
content: WASHINGTON — Widespread drug abuse, substandard medical and mental health care, out-of-control violence and horrific sanitary conditions are rampant at a federal prison in Atlanta, a new congressional investigation into the federal Bureau of Prisons has found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: How We Communicate Will Decide Whether Democracy Lives or Dies
description: The journalist Sean Illing explains how TV, Twitter and TikTok shape our brains — and our politics.
content: “At the very heart of democracy is a contradiction that cannot be resolved, one that has affected free societies from ancient Greece to contemporary America,” write Zac Gershberg and Sean Illing in their new book, “The Paradox of Democracy.” In order to live up to its name, democracy must be open to free communication and expression; yet that very feature opens democracies up to the forces of chaos, fragmentation and demagoguery that undermine them. Historically, this paradox becomes particularly profound during transitions between different communication technologies. “We see this time and again,” Gershberg and Illing write, “media continually evolve faster than politics, resulting in recurring patterns of democratic instability.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: As the Trade Deadline Nears, the Brewers Could Be in Trouble
description: Expected to cruise to a second straight division title, Milwaukee may need reinforcements if it wants to hold off St. Louis. Even a wild-card berth could be in doubt.
content: After winning 95 games last year, and bringing back a team with three legitimate aces in its rotation and a lineup loaded with power — all under the direction of Craig Counsell, whom some view as the best manager in baseball — the Milwaukee Brewers were a popular pick to repeat as champions of the National League Central.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: Tamales in the Village, Whole Lobster and More Reader Questions
description: A tennis fan seeks a delicious meal on the way back to Manhattan from the U.S. Open in Queens.
content: Hello from the final week of July! Summer is fully in swing — are you eating your daily ice cream? — and the requests keep coming. This week, I’m helping a reader who will be in town for the U.S. Open and needs recommendations for where to dine in Manhattan and on the way back from the stadium in Flushing. Also, a reader is searching for great tamales in the Village, and another wants to eat whole lobster without breaking the bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Rediscovering Australia’s Generation of Defiant Female Directors
description: Gillian Armstrong, Jane Campion, Essie Coffey and others had waited years to tell their stories, as a Museum of the Moving Image series shows.
content: In the opening moments of Gillian Armstrong’s debut feature, “My Brilliant Career” (1979), a freckled, tawny-haired young woman stands in the doorway of her house in the Australian outback and declares: “Dear countrymen, a few lines to let you know that this story is going to be all about me.” The woman is Sybylla, played by a fiery, young Judy Davis, and she dreams of a long, fruitful career as a writer — love, marriage, motherhood and all of society’s other expectations be damned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: The Case of the $5,000 Springsteen Tickets
description: Triumphant fans showed up in Ticketmaster’s queue with special codes, only to encounter its “dynamic pricing” system. Was the Boss OK with that?
content: For in-the-know fans who wanted to buy Bruce Springsteen tickets this month, applying for a special Ticketmaster access code seemed the best way to beat long odds. If they got one, they would have an opportunity to try to make it to the front of the service’s virtual queues on the days when batches of shows were up for sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Highbrow Fashion in Gritty Spaces
description: These global brands made a splash in New York by going super-local.
content: The Cock is a low-ceilinged, pitch-dark East Village dive that has been described by one website as “the last filthy gay bar in New York.” It shuns publicity, having been frequently raided by police back in the 1990s during the Giuliani administration, and is infamous for its cruisy sex scene. For those reasons, it seems an unlikely site for party hosted by a luxury fashion company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Viral Infections and Gene Variant Are Linked to Child Hepatitis Cases
description: Some of the children were infected with adeno-associated virus 2 and shared a relatively uncommon gene variant, according to two small studies.
content: A complex combination of factors could be responsible for the pediatric hepatitis cases that have been puzzling doctors in recent months, according to two small, new studies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: How Much Should I Spend to Keep My Elderly Dog Alive?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to do right by our pets as they reach the end of life.
content: I am a 65-year-old single retired woman who has sufficient means to take care of herself, though I need to watch my budget. My 15-year-old dog has been largely healthy for much of his life. I really love him, but I can see that in the next year or two there will be hard choices about how much money to spend on his care as he ages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Remy Tumin
title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Facing ‘Putin’s Energy Blackmail,’ Europe Agrees to Cut Russian Gas Use
description: Holding together despite some nations’ dependence on Russia, the European Union agreed to make voluntary savings mandatory if the Kremlin suddenly decides to turn off the taps over its invasion of Ukraine.
content: BRUSSELS — Fearing Russia could shut the taps this winter, the European Union agreed to a deal on Tuesday to curb natural gas consumption starting next week, the latest show of resolve and solidarity in its push and shove with the Kremlin over President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California Considers Extending Last Call to 4 A.M.
description: A proposal in the State Legislature would allow San Francisco, Fresno and Oakland to keep bars open for two extra hours.
content: Anyone who has spent a late night at a bar has heard the echoes of “last call,” the signal that the final drinks of the night are being served and that soon it will be time to head home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The I.M.F. warns that a global recession could soon be at hand.
description: The International Monetary Fund downgraded its growth forecasts and projected higher inflation around the world.
content: The world could soon be on the brink of a global recession as the economies of the United States, China and Europe slow more sharply than anticipated amid a collision of crises, the International Monetary Fund warned on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Says It Will Quit the International Space Station After 2024
description: The withdrawal would end two decades of post-Cold War cooperation in space between the United States and Russia, which jointly built and operate the station.
content: As the race to the moon receded, American and Soviet astronauts met and shook hands in space for the first time in 1975. The United States and Russia continued to work together in outer space, looking beyond their hostilities on Earth, culminating in the 1990s with the two nations jointly building and operating a laboratory in space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: A Rabbi, a Minister and an Imam Walk Into Lincoln Center
description: Before the trio of clergy, and guests including Mayor Eric Adams, hundreds of couples celebrated a symbolic wedding at the performing arts campus.
content: Lea DeLaria, the actress-comedian, surveyed the crowd that had gathered on a recent Sunday evening at the Damrosch Park band shell at Lincoln Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: In San Antonio, the Poor Live on Their Own Islands of Heat
description: Texas has been hit with an unrelenting heat wave. Nowhere is it more miserable than in low-income areas that have less access to shade and air-conditioning.
content: SAN ANTONIO — One day last week, Juanita Cruz-Perez poked her head out the back door of her two-bedroom home in San Antonio and shook her head no. It wasn’t quite noon yet, and the heat was already unbearable. She opened the front and back doors, praying for any kind of breeze, and turned on a plastic fan that sputtered hot air. She resisted the temptation to turn on the power-guzzling air-conditioner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 6, Episode 10 Recap: Sweet Revenge
description: Gene Takavic, a.k.a, Saul Goodman, thwarts an enemy using little more than his wits and a lot of sugar.
content: A mystery has lurked in the post-“Breaking Bad” timeline of “Better Call Saul,” when our favorite plaintiff’s attorney has become Gene Takavic, manager of a Cinnabon at an Omaha mall. Each season of “Better Call Saul” has opened with a few minutes of Gene’s life, shot in black and white, a glimpse at a life filled with frosting, tedium and dread. Saul is an hourly wage drudge who lives alone and constantly scans for anyone who might recognize him from his days as a wanted man in the aftermath of “Breaking Bad” infamy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: Summer Loving
description: To celebrate this sticky seventh month, we present seven of our favorite summer-themed Tiny Love Stories.
content: A very drunk man won’t stop telling me about trains. The Cape Town summer is hot, the night sticky, my drink warm. This gay bar will surely sink, given the number of heaving bodies shoved inside it. I nod at the train-talker, plotting an escape, and you appear. Your accent is cute, your beard cuter, and you tell the train guy that we’re here together. Suddenly, we are here together. It isn’t a lie; it’s a prophecy, and a good one at that. Ten years, three countries, five cities, four dogs and two toddlers later, we’re still here, together. — Michael McClelland
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Our Leaderless Free World
description: Biden seems to be mastering the trick of turning lemonade into lemons.
content: The central fact about the democratic world today is that it is leaderless.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Sean Illing
description: A conversation with the journalist Sean Illing.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Sean Illing. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Hope Solo, Former U.S. Soccer Star, Pleads Guilty to Driving Impaired
description: Ms. Solo had a blood-alcohol level of three times the legal limit while in a car with her two children, the authorities said.
content: Hope Solo, a former star goalie with the U.S. women’s soccer team, pleaded guilty on Monday to driving while impaired, four months after she was found passed out behind the wheel in the parking lot of a Walmart in Winston-Salem, N.C., with her two children in the back seat, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Le Rock, From the Frenchette Team, Opens in Rockefeller Center
description: A Washington, D.C., destination from José Andrés puts down Manhattan roots; a Benoit alumnus anchors a SoHo French restaurant; and more restaurant news.
content: Every few decades, the reset button is pressed on the restaurants in Rockefeller Center. A big year was 1984, with the openings of the Sea Grill and American Festival Cafe by Restaurant Associates. This year promises to be notable as well, with Tishman Speyer, the company that owns and operates Rockefeller Center, continuing to shape the dining scene. A major addition is Le Rock, Lee Hanson and Riad Nasr’s grand interpretation of a French brasserie. (Mr. Hanson and Mr. Nasr, veterans of Balthazar, own Frenchette in TriBeCa and have Le Veau d’Or on the Upper East Side in the wings.) With Workstead, a Brooklyn interior design studio, they have incorporated enough Art Deco features to anchor the soaring room to its historic setting. A verdigris screen separates the bar, terrazzo floors are new but don’t look it and bare burled wood tables sit at forest-green leather banquettes. Mr. Hanson and Mr. Nasr have to fill 130 seats indoors with another 70 on the terrace, and, to do so, especially with a potential tourist audience, they have given an international spin to the menu. “We’ve gone simpler than Frenchette, which has its own personality,” Mr. Hanson said. Mr. Nasr cited some classic brasserie items, like leeks vinaigrette, escargots, pâté maison and steak au poivre (made with bison). They share a menu, divided into Cette Semaine (weekly specials) and Tout le Temps (every day), which also lists falafel, a brochette of calamari and shishito peppers, and barbajuans, a kind of fried ravioli. Some items play it coy, using untranslated French names, like tablier de sapeur (breaded tripe) and cervelle de canut (fresh herbed cheese). In charge of the kitchen as executive chef is Walker Stern, a former owner of Battersby and Dover in Brooklyn. Mariah Neston is collaborating with Michelle Palazzo, the head pastry chef, on site to create a giant baba au rhum carved tableside. Dinner gets things rolling, with breakfast, which they do not serve at Frenchette, and lunch to follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: B.J. Novak Went to Texas Looking for ‘Vengeance’ and Found America
description: The first film from a former star of “The Office” is a dark comedy about life in a nation that’s not as divided as we might think.
content: A funny story that B.J. Novak likes to tell from the making of his new movie is about the day he thought he was having a stroke. Are you chuckling yet?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: ‘Dangerous’ Heat Engulfs the Pacific Northwest
description: The region is preparing for consecutive days of 100-degree heat.
content: A major heat wave settling over the Pacific Northwest will bring several days of potentially record-breaking triple-digit temperatures this week, echoing a deadly heat wave that tormented the region last summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Kolker
title: Why Was Joshua Held for More Than Two Years for Someone Else’s Crimes?
description: Honolulu incarcerated the wrong man for more than two years — a miscarriage of justice that shows the cruel inadequacy of America’s approach to mental health.
content: On May 11, 2017, the River of Life Mission in Honolulu’s Chinatown was serving food when a 46-year-old man named Joshua Spriestersbach lined up. For more than a century, the neighborhood has been a gathering place for the city’s homeless, its sidewalks often jammed with people sleeping, sometimes setting up encampments for days or longer. A variety of organizations have sprung up to attack root causes — meth addiction, mental illness, lack of housing — but the most reliable meal service came from the River of Life, a charity with a storefront, a few blocks from the harbor, that always draws a line around the block. Spriestersbach was a regular. He would go from the park to the soup kitchen and back again, never without a newsboy cap, never interacting with anyone if he could help it. On that day in May, he was sitting on the sidewalk when a police officer approached him and placed him under arrest. There’d been no altercation, no incident, no fight. Later, he would say he thought it was because he fell asleep in line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: After Enduring a Pandemic, Small Businesses Face New Worries
description: It has been a tough few years for companies without the scale to cruise through disruption. Making money isn’t getting any easier.
content: America’s small businesses can’t catch a break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Specktor
title: A Tale of Golden Age Hollywood, Co-Starring Art and Agitprop
description: In Anthony Marra’s new novel, “Mercury Pictures Presents,” a studio makes it big once America decides to enter the war.
content: The line between art and agitprop can be narrow, and rarely more so than in Hollywood, where people sometimes struggle to know (or care) what art is to begin with.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Ukraine Prepares an Ambitious Counterattack
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 26, 2022.
content: “We’ve put our trust in God and in our bomb shelter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater
title: ‘Kind of Wild/Creative’: Emails Shed Light on Trump Fake Electors Plan
description: Previously undisclosed communications among Trump campaign aides and outside advisers provide new insight into their efforts to overturn the election in the weeks leading to Jan. 6.
content: Previously undisclosed emails provide an inside look at the increasingly desperate and often slapdash efforts by advisers to President Donald J. Trump to reverse his election defeat in the weeks before the Jan. 6 attack, including acknowledgments that a key element of their plan was of dubious legality and lived up to its billing as “fake.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: The Choco Taco, Ice Cream Snack of American Summers, Is Discontinued
description: A fixture of ice cream trucks and convenience stores is no more after Klondike said it would focus on other products.
content: The Choco Taco, a nut-and-chocolate-topped ice cream snack that for decades has been a top choice at the ice cream truck or convenience store freezer, is being discontinued, its creator confirmed this week after weeks of rumors about its impending demise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Jay Root
title: How Did a Man Accused of Attacking Lee Zeldin Go Free Without Bail?
description: The decision to release the suspect was seen by some Democrats as a ploy to fuel Mr. Zeldin’s anti-crime campaign as he runs for governor of New York.
content: It did not take long for the attack on Representative Lee Zeldin during a campaign event to become the latest flash point in the political fight over New York’s bail laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Lai
title: Transportation Dept. Opens Program to Make Public Transit Accessible
description: The initiative, included in last year’s infrastructure law, makes $1.75 billion available for cities to make transit stations more accessible to disabled people.
content: WASHINGTON — The Department of Transportation opened a program on Tuesday that allows cities to apply for federal funding to make public transit stations more accessible to disabled people, moving on the anniversary of the Americans With Disabilities Act to provide access to $1.75 billion to update stations that do not comply with the law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Republicans Confront Unexpected Online Money Slowdown
description: In an otherwise favorable political climate, small-dollar donations have dropped for Republicans, making the party more reliant on megadonors to compete.
content: Online fund-raising has slowed across much of the Republican Party in recent months, an unusual pullback of small donors that has set off a mad rush among Republican political operatives to understand why — and reverse the sudden decline before it damages the party’s chances this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: He Didn’t Plan to Buy a Place on Fire Island. But This Was No Ordinary Home.
description: If I.M. Pei’s Louvre Pyramid was a shingled beach house in the Pines, it might look something like this. How could he resist?
content: Glenn Rice’s journey to owning a house on Fire Island, N.Y., began unexpectedly in Boston and was propelled, surprisingly, by his love of theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: A Maestro and His Musicians Face Scrutiny Over Ties to Russia
description: Teodor Currentzis and the ensemble MusicAeterna have faced backlash in the West over their partnership with a state-owned bank in Russia.
content: SALZBURG, Austria — Teodor Currentzis is revered as one of classical music’s most original voices, a rebellious conductor who can breathe fresh life into well-known works. In this European cultural capital, where artists, agents and impresarios gather each summer, he is omnipresent, his name emblazoned on banners and brochures. His fans travel from around the world to hear his performances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Brittney Griner’s Lawyers Argue for Leniency in Russian Court
description: The W.N.B.A. star had not intended to smuggle drugs into Russia, her legal team said, adding that, like many other international athletes, she had used cannabis to help ease pain from injuries.
content: Wearing a black and gray sweatshirt with the slogan “Black lives for peace” printed on the back, Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. star who has been detained in Russia on drug charges, appeared in a court near Moscow on Tuesday as her defense team continued to present evidence that she had not intended to break the law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Third Set of Human Remains Is Found at Lake Mead Since May
description: It was unclear if the falling water levels at the lake outside Las Vegas played a role in the discovery.
content: Human remains were discovered at Lake Mead National Recreational Area in Nevada on Monday, the third such discovery in recent months as the lake has reached dangerously low water levels, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Tunisians Approve New Constitution That Undercuts Democracy
description: The charter, passed in a referendum, cements the almost absolute power that President Kais Saied seized over the past year, when he has ruled mostly by decree.
content: Tunisians approved a new Constitution that cements the one-man rule instituted by President Kais Saied over the past year, according to the results of a referendum released on Tuesday, dealing a body blow to a democracy built with immense effort and high hopes after the overthrow of the country’s dictator more than a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Europe Weans Itself Off Russian Gas
description: It will start rationing to make it through winter.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Teva Reaches Tentative $4.25 Billion Settlement Over Opioids
description: The deal would end thousands of lawsuits against one of the largest producers of opioid painkillers during the height of the opioid epidemic.
content: Teva Pharmaceuticals, one of the country’s biggest manufacturers of generic opioids, announced a settlement in principle with some 2,500 local governments, states and tribes over the company’s role in the deadly, ongoing opioid epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Buzz Aldrin’s Space Memorabilia Sells for More Than $8 Million
description: A jacket that the astronaut wore during the Apollo 11 mission to the moon in 1969 and his Presidential Medal of Freedom were among the items auctioned off by Sotheby’s in New York City.
content: A white, Teflon-coated jacket worn by the astronaut Buzz Aldrin during the Apollo 11 mission to the moon in 1969 sold for $2.7 million at a Sotheby’s auction on Tuesday, fetching the highest price among dozens of pieces of rare memorabilia tracing his career in space exploration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: With Crisis Everywhere, Do Democracies Have an Edge?
description: The challenges of pandemic and climate change are being closely studied, but have done little so far to settle the eternal debate over whether authoritarian governments or democracies fare better in hard times.
content: A debate has long raged at universities and think tanks, through public diplomacy and state media outlets: Does democracy or an authoritarian system perform better in times of crisis?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Peter Baker
title: Biden tries to persuade Americans that the U.S. is not in a recession.
description: The president and his aides spoke days before the latest data on the nation’s economic growth is due to be released.
content: President Biden and his aides on Monday escalated a campaign to try to convince American voters that the nation has not fallen into recession, before the release this week of new data that could show the economy continues to shrink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Adesina
title: Black Portraits Get New Names, and a New Show
description: Glyn Philpot’s sensitive portraits of Black subjects, unusual for the early 20th century, were given updated titles — and consideration — for a recent exhibition in England.
content: LONDON — In the early 20th century, Glyn Philpot was one of Britain’s most respected portrait painters. The artist was known for depicting high-society sitters in a style mimicking the old masters, so his works sat comfortably on the walls of his clients’ country homes alongside generations of their family members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Quandt
title: After Two Decades in Solitary, This Is His First Day Out
description: After nearly 33 years in prison — and over two decades in solitary confinement — Jack Powers embarks on the first day of his new life.
content: I was introduced to Jack Powers during his final month of nearly 33 years spent in prison. A former bank robber, Mr. Powers spent over two decades in solitary confinement, most of them in the notorious maximum-security prison known as the ADX.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Democrats Aid Far-Right Candidate Against Republican Who Backed Impeachment
description: A new ad for John Gibbs in his primary against Representative Peter Meijer in Michigan is the latest Democratic effort to highlight candidates they think will be easier to beat this fall.
content: The House Democrats’ official campaign arm is stepping into a Western Michigan Republican primary to elevate a candidate endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump against one of the 10 House Republicans who voted to impeach him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: U.S. Authors Dominate Booker Prize Nominees
description: Six of the 13 writers in contention for the prestigious British literary award are from the United States, with novelists from Britain, Ireland and Zimbabwe also on the list.
content: LONDON — Elizabeth Strout, Karen Joy Fowler and Leila Mottley are among six American authors nominated for this year’s Booker Prize, which announced its nominees in a news release on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Shao
title: How Is Climate Change Affecting Floods?
description: Like other extreme weather disasters, flooding involves a number of competing factors that may affect its frequency and intensity.
content: Floods can surge all year round, in every region of the world. But discerning the relationship between any given flood and climate change is no small feat, experts say, made difficult by limited historical records, particularly for the most extreme floods, which occur infrequently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Senator Raphael Warnock uses a new ad to pressure Herschel Walker to commit to a debate.
description: Mr. Walker has repeatedly pledged to debate Mr. Warnock, but his campaign has not accepted invitations to any of the matchups scheduled in Georgia.
content: ATLANTA — A new advertisement from Raphael Warnock, Georgia’s incumbent Democratic senator, pushes the state’s Republican Senate nominee, Herschel Walker, to debate Mr. Warnock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Parents of British Boy Lose Appeal to Keep Him on Life Support
description: Archie Battersbee, 12, was found with something tied around his neck, and was determined to have severe brain damage. His parents may try to take the case to the European Court of Human Rights.
content: LONDON — The parents of a 12-year-old British boy in a deep coma lost an appeal to keep him on life support on Monday, in a case that has once again put a spotlight on who makes end-of-life decisions involving children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Melting Profits Threaten the Ice Cream Man
description: Inflation and its rising fuel prices have pushed some ice cream truck owners to the brink.
content: On a steamy evening at Flushing Meadows Corona Park in Queens, Jaime Cabal had a line of customers at his Mister Softee ice cream truck. He blended milkshakes, topped bowls of vanilla soft-serve with strawberries and dipped cones into cherry and blue-raspberry shell. One boy no sooner finished his treat than he begged his parents for more, pointing at the menu’s pops shaped like SpongeBob SquarePants, Sonic the Hedgehog and Tweety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: England Strolls to Wembley With Three Goals and One Stunner
description: Alessia Russo’s backheel helped her team rout Sweden and storm into Sunday’s Euro 2022 final.
content: SHEFFIELD, England — The crowd at Bramall Lane required three viewings before it could settle on the appropriate response. The first, in real time, prompted a jubilant, triumphal roar. The second, on the giant screen in a corner of the stadium as England’s players celebrated below, drew a gasp of appreciation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Virshup
title: Travel ‘Works to Shake Things Up,’ Says the Novelist Emily Henry
description: The author of best-selling rom-com novels, including this summer’s “Book Lovers,” likes to take her characters out of their comfort zones, and saw much of America from her family’s minivan.
content: Over the last three years, the novelist Emily Henry has established a solid beachhead on summertime best seller lists with a series of travel-related rom-coms, starting with “Beach Read” in 2020, and followed by last summer’s “People We Meet on Vacation” and this year’s “Book Lovers.” All three novels currently share space on The Times’s combined Print and E-book fiction list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters and Benjamin Mullin
title: OAN, a Dependable Trump Promoter, Faces a ‘Death Blow’
description: After Verizon drops the network at the end of this week, OAN’s cable TV audience will shrink dramatically.
content: The future of One America News, which established itself as a powerful voice in conservative media by promoting some of the most outlandish falsehoods about the 2020 election, is in serious doubt as major carriers drop it from their lineups and defamation lawsuits threaten to drain its finances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Few Parents Intend to Have Very Young Children Vaccinated Against Covid
description: In a new survey, 43 percent of parents of children ages 6 months through 4 years said they would refuse the shots for their kids. An additional 27 percent were uncertain.
content: Barely a month after the Food and Drug Administration authorized Covid-19 vaccines for very young children, the prognosis that large numbers of them will actually get the shots looks bleak, according to a new survey of parents released on Tuesday by the Kaiser Family Foundation, which has monitored vaccine attitudes throughout the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: A Global Inflation Crisis
description: Big price increases are not exclusive to the U.S.
content: Inflation has dominated the news about America’s economy in recent months as prices for food, gas and other goods have increased faster than they have in four decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Study Shows Disability Representation Onscreen Is Increasing, but Still Falls Short
description: The study published Tuesday also showed that television continues to lag behind film when it comes to representation of characters with disabilities.
content: “CODA,” a film about the hearing child of deaf parents, won this year’s Academy Award for best picture, and one of its stars, Troy Kotsur, became the first deaf man to win an acting Oscar when he took home the award for best supporting actor. Lauren Ridloff became the Marvel Cinematic Universe’s first deaf superhero in “Eternals.” The Hulu mystery-comedy series “Only Murders in the Building” won acclaim for an almost entirely silent episode that highlighted the perspective of a deaf character (played by James Caverly).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian, Isabella Simonetti and Julie Creswell
title: More Signs Emerge That Inflation Is Altering Shopping Habits
description: Coca-Cola, McDonald’s and Unilever said some consumers were shifting their spending in response to rapidly rising prices, after Walmart rattled the market with a warning about unsold inventory.
content: A day after Walmart warned investors that its profit would shrink as rising prices forced shoppers to make fewer purchases at its stores, Unilever, Coca-Cola and McDonald’s, three other consumer-facing giants, reinforced the message, to different degrees, providing a window into how companies are navigating this fragile economic moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Newman
title: The Power of Negative Thinking
description: Need permission to be a grump — or just a normal human being who isn’t smiling all the time? Read these books.
content: Recently a friend posted on Facebook that, after years of struggle against two different kinds of cancer, she was going into hospice care. She is smart, funny and unafraid. Her heartbreaking news generated the expected outpouring of love and support, including a number of messages repeating the popular current sentiment: You got this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Lashes Trump Over Jan. 6, Saying He ‘Lacked the Courage to Act’
description: In rare comments on the investigation unfolding in the House, President Biden said his predecessor sat in the comfort of the White House as his supporters stormed the Capitol.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Monday denounced former President Donald J. Trump’s refusal to decisively intervene to stop the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, declaring that his predecessor “lacked the courage to act” and betrayed the police officers he claimed to support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Kraken, a U.S. Crypto Exchange, Is Suspected of Violating Sanctions
description: The Treasury Department is investigating whether the crypto exchange allowed users in Iran to buy and sell digital tokens, said people with knowledge of the matter.
content: Kraken, one of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchanges, is under federal investigation, suspected of violating U.S. sanctions by allowing users in Iran and elsewhere to buy and sell digital tokens, according to five people affiliated with the company or with knowledge of the inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Johnson
title: Sex Confessions and Protest From a Disillusioned Communist
description: Wang Xiaobo’s “The Golden Age” is a novel of lust and loss during China’s Cultural Revolution.
content: In 1991, a little-known writer in Beijing named Wang Xiaobo mailed the manuscript of a novel to the eminent historian Cho-yun Hsu, his former professor at the University of Pittsburgh. The book was about China’s Cultural Revolution, the political purge from 1966 to 1976 that killed more than a million people and sent scientists, writers, artists and millions of educated youths to labor in the countryside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Williams
title: Need for Speed Spurs Demand for Move-In-Ready Buildings
description: As vacancies for industrial space tighten, developers are building warehouses and labs on speculation, hoping a tenant will lease the space when construction is done.
content: WEST CHESTER, Ohio — Suburban spillover has long been chewing away at the bucolic countryside around Cincinnati. Twenty-five years ago, the growth was powered by affordable housing and award-winning schools. But, as the economy has changed, so have the demands for space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Is Recession Staring Us Down? Already Upon Us? Here’s Why It’s Hard to Say.
description: The U.S. may register a second straight quarter of economic contraction, one benchmark of a recession. But that won’t be the last word.
content: The United States is not in a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: Fentanyl From the Government? A Vancouver Experiment Aims to Stop Overdoses
description: A city on the forefront of harm reduction has taken the concept to a new level in an effort to address the growing toxicity of street drugs.
content: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — The place where Chris gets his fentanyl is bright and airy, all blond wood and exposed brick. The staff is friendly and knowledgeable about the potency of the pills he can crush, cook and inject.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Small Recession Shouldn’t Stop Eurozone Rate Increases, E.C.B. Policymaker Says
description: Pierre Wunsch, a member of the European Central Bank’s Governing Council, said the deposit rate should probably reach at least 1.5 percent.
content: The European Central Bank should keep raising interest rates to tackle inflation even if the eurozone slips into a recession, said Pierre Wunsch, a member of the bank’s Governing Council and the head of Belgium’s central bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Szalavitz
title: The War on Drugs Has a Warning for Post-Roe America
description: Medicine is hard to govern with the blunt instrument of criminal law.
content: With the fall of Roe v. Wade, physicians across the country are struggling to balance the conflicting imperatives of their calling to care with their institutional duty to avoid legal liability, all to the detriment of their patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Grass Fire Destroys or Damages 20 Homes Outside Dallas
description: The fire was mostly contained by Monday evening, but not before it swept through a row of houses in Balch Springs, where the blaze had rapidly spread.
content: A fast-moving grass fire swept through a suburban neighborhood near Dallas on Monday, destroying or damaging at least 20 homes, displacing about 20 people and forcing evacuations as firefighters struggled to fight back flames in 103-degree heat, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Pomerantsev
title: Ukraine Is the Next Act in Putin’s Empire of Humiliation
description: There seems to be nothing in Russia’s mainstream discourse that takes responsibility for the past and imagines a different path forward.
content: Valentyna told me that not long after Russian troops arrived in Yahidne, her village in northern Ukraine, a tall, blond soldier came to use her bathroom. She asked him what the Russians were doing in Ukraine. “We want you to be with us,” he told her, “for you to be with Russia.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Weike Wang
title: A Novel About Riding and Seeking
description: “The Boys” begins with a letter from a bike touring company, asking the main character not to sign up for another trip. Why?
content: Katie Hafner’s taut and utterly delightful debut is a novel of multitudes. It is travel escapism, a family drama, a character study, social commentary on pandemic isolation and an incredible journey back to center. We are emerging from a period of forced introversion, and “The Boys” provides the perfect antidote. For anyone who now feels anxious about leaving the house or traveling abroad or re-entering the world, you will find, as I did, a kindred spirit in Ethan Fawcett.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson, Christine Hauser and Eric Berger
title: Flash Floods Swamp St. Louis Area, Breaking a Century-Old Rain Record
description: One person died after being pulled from a flooded vehicle, and property damage was “very significant” in some hard-hit areas, the city’s fire chief said.
content: Just three days ago, the River Des Peres, which carries storm water from the city of St. Louis, was “almost bone dry,” the city’s fire chief said, as Missouri experienced what the governor called increasingly dry conditions and the growing threat of serious drought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Mocks Trump for His Imaginary Friends
description: Meyers noted that Trump’s speeches frequently have him “whining incessantly about how he’s being treated or repeating some weird lie an imaginary friend supposedly told him.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Francesca Paris
title: Records Fell at the Track Worlds. A Trend? Not So Fast.
description: Some have referred to this era as a golden age of better and better times. But a deeper look at the data shows the simple shorthand conclusion is incomplete.
content: The highlight of the track and field world championships, which wrapped up in Eugene, Ore., on Sunday, was undoubtedly Sydney McLaughlin’s shattering her own world record, and the rest of the field, in the 400-meter hurdles. It was a record set in dominant fashion, the type of performance fans watch sports for but rarely actually get to see.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Editors’ Note
description: An obituary of the actor Tony Dow was published in error. The Times based the confirmation of his death on a Facebook post by his representatives, which proved erroneous and has since been deleted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: Shopify is laying off 10 percent of its workers.
description: The e-commerce platform made the “wrong” bet on the continued boom in online shopping, the chief executive said in a memo to employees.
content: Shopify, the online marketplace, is laying off about 10 percent of its 10,000 employees, the company’s chief executive announced Tuesday, citing stagnating growth in the e-commerce space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Wehner
title: What in the World Happened to Elise Stefanik?
description: The changing politics of the No. 3 House Republican leader tell us a lot about the transformation of the G.O.P.
content: There was a time in 2016 when Elise Stefanik, now the third-ranking Republican in the House, was so disgusted by Donald Trump, she would barely mention his name. Today he proudly refers to her as “one of my killers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Trump-Pence Ticket, Torn by Jan. 6, Becomes an Unequal Rivalry
description: Trailed by the Capitol riot fallout and 2024 speculation, the two erstwhile allies gave competing speeches that revealed the Republican Party’s enduring challenges and divisions.
content: WASHINGTON — Eighteen months after departing the nation’s capital for the final time as president, Donald J. Trump returned on Tuesday confronting federal investigations, fresh doubts about his viability in an increasingly likely third White House bid and an emerging rivalry with his erstwhile running mate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Federal Government Fires Up Website All About Heat
description: Concerned about the growing severity of heat waves, the government created heat.gov to help Americans stay safe in sweltering conditions.
content: The Biden administration unveiled a website on Tuesday to help Americans stay safe from extreme heat, as scorching temperatures continued to grip portions of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Some Time
description: Lillian Simpson’s Tuesday puzzle is one you won’t want to miss.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the constructor of today’s grid, Lillian Simpson, who is making her debut in the New York Times Crossword. Without spoiling it, the theme in this puzzle is one of my favorites in a while. There’s also a lot of fun fill in here, and I particularly enjoyed the entries at 20- and 50-Across as well as 9-, 22- and 26-Down. I hope you have as much fun solving this puzzle as I did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Microsoft reports earnings that fall short of already-reduced expectations.
description: The tech giant cited the strong U.S. dollar, falling consumer demand and production slowdowns of PCs for its performance.
content: SEATTLE — The uncertainty and challenges in the global economy have hit Microsoft, which on Tuesday reported quarterly earnings that fell short of Wall Street’s and its own expectations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden
title: Former California Corrections Officer Admits Assaulting Inmates and Lying
description: Arturo Pacheco, 40, knocked an inmate to the ground, breaking his jaw and several teeth, prosecutors said. The inmate died two days later.
content: A former California correctional officer pleaded guilty on Monday to federal charges, admitting that he had covered up the assault of two inmates, one of whom died, and then boasted about it in text messages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: Will China Move on Taiwan?
description: An escalation from Beijing would have far-reaching economic consequences.
content: Unilever, the consumer goods giant, said this morning that it was raising prices to offset a decline in sales, a day after Walmart, the nation’s largest retailer, cut its profit outlook because of reduced consumer spending. It’s a stark sign of how inflation is affecting retailers, which have struggled with rising inventory, and squeezing consumers. General Motors said its quarterly profits were down 40 percent, amid rising costs and a continuing computer-chip shortage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Laura Boushnak
title: Kyiv Nightlife Comes Back Amid Urge for Contact. ‘This Is the Cure.’
description: Frenzied raves. Crowded bars (with free therapy). And of course, cuddle parties. Nightlife is returning to Ukraine’s capital. But revelers still have to reckon with guilty feelings. Plus curfew.
content: KYIV — The rave had been planned for weeks, with the space secured and the D.J.s, the drinks, the invites and the security all lined up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: A Judge Halts New York City School Budget Cuts, for Now
description: Parents sued the city over plans to cut money to schools that have lost students, even as the mayor and City Council try to make a deal to restore funds.
content: More than $200 million in cuts to New York City public schools have been put on hold by a Manhattan judge, the latest move in an escalating fight over how to fund schools that involves Mayor Eric Adams, the City Council and an increasingly vocal and enraged group of parents and educators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Ian Austen
title: Pope Apologizes in Canada for Schools That Abused Indigenous Children
description: Francis, responding to longtime pleas from Indigenous people, begged forgiveness for schools where children were forced to assimilate, many were sexually or physically abused and some died.
content: MASKWACIS, Alberta — Pope Francis offered a sweeping apology directly to Indigenous people on their land in Canada on Monday, fulfilling a critical demand of many of the survivors of church-run residential schools that became gruesome centers of abuse, forced assimilation, cultural devastation and death for over a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalley Huang
title: Instagram, facing criticism from Kylie Jenner and others, tries explaining itself.
description: Meta is meeting backlash for changes that make some of its platforms act more like TikTok.
content: Instagram versus the Great Celebrity Gang-Up?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur
title: For Investors and a Buffer, Alibaba Seeks a Hong Kong Primary Listing
description: The Chinese e-commerce giant’s application could give it better access to Chinese capital and a safety net against U.S. regulations.
content: Alibaba, the Chinese online shopping giant, said on Tuesday that it would seek a primary listing in Hong Kong, a move that would eventually allow more people in mainland China to invest in it, and give it a buffer in case it is forced to delist in the United States over regulatory concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: How Can Democrats Persuade Voters They’re Not a Party of Rich Elites?
description: That big question was the focus of a Tuesday gathering of progressive lawmakers, activists and scholars.
content: Today, at an unassuming event space in Washington overlooking the Capitol, a coterie of progressive thinkers and doers gathered for an intimate conference that could not have been more different from the boisterous gathering hosted just down the road by the conservative America First Policy Institute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Ukraine prepares for a counteroffensive.
content: Ukrainian forces are preparing for a high-stakes counteroffensive to retake Kherson, a crucial Russian stronghold in southern Ukraine. Moscow uses the vital port city as a base to launch attacks across a large part of Ukrainian territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Will Reid, Sydney Harper, Diana Nguyen, M.J. Davis Lin, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: How Roe’s Demise Could Safeguard Gay Marriage
description: A bill to protect marriage equality might now, improbably, become law.
content: After Roe v. Wade was overturned, Democrats introduced a bill to prevent the right to gay marriage from meeting the same fate as the right to abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Rabkin Peachman
title: A Lawsuit Claims Skittles Are Unfit for Consumption. Experts Weigh In.
description: They contain the food additive titanium dioxide, which is in thousands of food products. Here’s what we learned about its safety.
content: If you’ve been paying attention to nutrition headlines lately, you may have noticed a recent lawsuit that claimed that Skittles — the colorful candies of “taste the rainbow” fame — were “unfit for human consumption” because of the presence of a “known toxin” called titanium dioxide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: The E.U. Agrees to Curb Its Gas Consumption
description: Also, the I.M.F. warns of a global recession and U.S. concern for Taiwan grows.
content: The E.U. agreed to a deal to curb natural gas consumption starting next week, the latest show of solidarity in its efforts to punish Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Biden’s Big, Bold, Surprising Plan for a Green Transition (I Hope)
description: Our energy policy is a mess. The president needs to devise a new strategy with America’s biggest oil producers.
content: While it’s important that the U.S. maintain its longstanding alliance with Saudi Arabia, I wish President Biden had used Zoom for his recent meeting with the Saudi leadership. It was a bad look and bad energy policy for the U.S. president to fly all the way to Saudi Arabia to plead for more oil output when all he had to do was fly to Houston.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Subway Car 9075, Where Are You?
description: A “redbird” car from the 1960s was auctioned off for $235,700. Its future whereabouts and purpose are unknown.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today, trains, planes and no automobiles (except in the daily update about alternate-side parking).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: With ‘Surface,’ Gugu Mbatha-Raw Steps Into New Territory
description: The British actress has been prolific in film and television for the past decade, but a new Apple TV+ show is her first time as an executive producer.
content: LONDON — A few minutes into “Surface,” a new eight-part series from Apple TV+, the central character, Sophie, played by Gugu Mbatha-Raw, asks her therapist a question:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: The Big, Bold Life of the Woman Who Brought Us the ‘It Girl’
description: Hilary A. Hallett’s “Inventing the It Girl” tells the story of the early Hollywood pioneer Elinor Glyn.
content: More than half a century before Stephen King’s “It” seized little children, Elinor Glyn’s “It” seized adult imaginations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: How Sign Language Evolves as Our World Does
description: Ubiquitous video technology and social media have given deaf people a new way to communicate. They’re using it to transform American Sign Language.
content: Ubiquitous video technology and social media have given deaf people a new way to communicate. They’re using it to transform American Sign Language.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Race to Beat Kyiv’s Curfew
description: The party is back on in Kyiv and young people are going out in droves for the first time since the war began. But a strict nighttime curfew lingers.
content: The party is back on in Kyiv and young people are going out in droves for the first time since the war began. But a strict nighttime curfew lingers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Decorating a Pyramidal House in the Pines
description: If I.M. Pei’s Louvre Pyramid was a shingled beach house in the Pines, it might look something like this.
content: If I.M. Pei’s Louvre Pyramid was a shingled beach house in the Pines, it might look something like this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Quandt
title: Tuesday Afternoon
description: After nearly 33 years in prison — and over two decades in solitary confinement — Jack Powers embarks on the first day of his new life.
content: After nearly 33 years in prison — and over two decades in solitary confinement — Jack Powers embarks on the first day of his new life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Record Rainfall Triggers Flash Floods in St. Louis Area
description: Officials reported rescues from residences and submerged vehicles.
content: Officials reported rescues from residences and submerged vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Move to the South and Change It?

title: Corrections: July 26, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, July 26, 2022.
content: An article on Saturday about a deal between Russian and Ukraine that would allow grain shipments misstated the price of wheat futures on Friday, July 22. Prices fell by more than 5 percent to around $7.60 per bushel, not $760 per bushel.
source.name: The New York Times
